title: Brazil Central Bank Cuts Benchmark Rate to Record Low
text:
BRASÍLIA—Brazil’s central bank cut its benchmark interest rate as expected Wednesday, as consumer price increases remain under control amid a yearslong economic slowdown that has defied government efforts to boost growth.

The bank cut the benchmark Selic rate to a record low of 5.5% from 6%, with at least one more trim expected to come this year. Economists surveyed weekly by the central bank see the Selic at 5% at year’s end.

“The consolidation of the benign scenario for prospective inflation should permit additional adjustment of the degree of stimulus,” the bank said in the statement announcing the rate cut.

The central bank’s survey predicts inflation will end the year at 3.45%, well below the bank’s target of 4.25%. The economists also forecast meager 0.87% gross-domestic-product growth, a pace unlikely to significantly reduce the country’s 11.8% jobless rate.

The rate-cutting cycle started in July will take time to show any effect on the real economy, said Western Asset’s chief economist in Brazil, Adauto Lima. He said consumers remain cautious, and unused production capacity means businesses have little reason to invest, giving the bank room to reduce rates more.

“Inflation is so low, and we are so close to the end of the year that there could be room for more cuts in subsequent meetings.” he said. “The landscape remains very benign” for prices.

The central bank has two more meetings this year, on Oct. 30 and Dec. 11

Brazil’s weak economic growth has prevented business from passing the cost of the recent depreciation of the real against the dollar on to consumers, Mr. Lima added. The real is trading at about 4.10 to the dollar, after reaching 3.74 in July.

The depreciation is part of a global weakening among emerging-market currencies, paired with domestic problems, economists say. The administration of Brazil’s new president, Jair Bolsonaro, is still working to put in place its agenda of economic changes it says would boost growth.

Mr. Bolsonaro has promised to trim government costs and cut the red tape he blames, at least partially, for sluggish business activity. His administration is pushing a sweeping pension overhaul that is forecast to save more than $200 billion over 10 years and is expected to be approved by the Senate in October. The administration is also calling for a simplification of Brazil’s complex tax code, while preparing a pipeline of privatizations.

The planned changes, which would extend market-friendly overhauls begun in 2016 after President Dilma Rousseff of the leftist Workers’ Party was removed from office, are likely to ensure relatively low borrowing costs in Brazil after decades of double-digit rates, according to Rafael Cardoso, an economist from Daycoval Asset investment firm.

Legislation passed under Ms. Rousseff’s successor capping public spending and simplifying labor law, among other changes, is already allowing interest rates to remain at historic lows without triggering inflation. As Mr. Bolsonaro’s economic proposals advance through Congress, the central bank might decide it can keep its benchmark lending rate at 5% through 2021, according to Mr. Cardoso.

“Brazil’s conditions have improved, meaning there’s less solvency risk, which allows for lower rates,” he said. “We can now live with lower borrowing costs.”

description: Brazil’s central bank cut its benchmark interest rate as expected, as consumer price increases remain under control amid a yearslong economic slowdown.
